results.title: Angotee: story of an eskimo boy
results.creator_credit: Douglas Wilkinson, Michael Spencer and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: The time is 1953 and the place is the eastern Arctic. Beginning with a scene in an igloo showing the birth of Angotee to Atootoo, wife of the hunter Koonuk, this film follows the events of a man’s growth from birth to maturity. During babyhood Angotee is secure in the protection of his mother. His childhood is free and happy as he plays games invented out of the skills he will need as a man. During adolescence he accompanies his father on the hunt and enters the company of men where he shoots his first seal. The story ends as Angotee leaves the parental igloo to set up his own abode as a family man and a hunter of the great snow-swept barrens. Awards: Durban; Trento; Toronto.

results.title: Angel food
results.creator_credit: Julia Bourke, Paul Fletcher, Anne Shenfield, Robert Stephenson and Victorian College of the Arts
results.brief_description: Animated film that charts the short-lived adventures of an intrepid strawberry as it evades a variety of kitchen hazards - including vicious utensils, distraction by a Busby Berkeley-style fruit mambo, and a seductive but ultimately deadly pot of melted chocolate - to fulfill its quest to sit atop a decadent whipped cream and meringue dessert. “A glossy tale with a sticky end.”
results.creator_credit_for_label: Julia Bourke, Paul Fletcher, Anne Shenfield, Robert Stephenson and Victorian College of the Arts

results.title: And I cried
results.brief_description: We live in a world besieged and besotted by image. Everyone, it seems, wants their fifteen minutes and plenty of people will do whatever it takes to get a piece of the celebrity cake. “And I cried” is a film about wishing to be a movie star. Being a star is about shining bright, a brilliant flash of light against a velvety black night sky. “And I cried” is an exploration, a celebration, a lamentation, of our obsession with the star and the image. Cast includes: Cassandra Tytler, Engelbert Schmidl, Dominic Redfern, Shane Hennessey.

results.title: Angels of war
results.creator_credit: Gavan Daws, Hank Nelson, Andrew Pike and Australian National University. Research School of Pacific Studies
results.brief_description: Papua New Guinea men recount their experiences when war came to their islands in 1942. During three years a million Americans, 300,000 Japanese and nearly half a million Australians fought their way across the country. Cut into their memories are archival film sequences shot by Japanese, American and Australian cameramen and the songs and poems of black men and white writing about life and death in time of war. Now the men speak passionately of the white man’s promises, made to them in war and never kept in peace.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Gavan Daws, Hank Nelson, Andrew Pike and Australian National University. Research School of Pacific Studies

results.title: An Interview with Douglas Margetts
results.creator_credit: Douglas Margetts and ACMI Digital Storytelling
results.brief_description: Douglas Margetts served as part of the Australian 6th Division Signals and served in the Middle East and New Guinea in World War II. He relates his experiences as part of “In our words”, a Digital Storytelling workshop for Victorian war veterans.

results.title: An Interview with Wing Commander Peter Isaacson : Chairman of the Shrine of Remembrance Trustees (1983-2000)
results.creator_credit: Peter Isaacson and ACMI Digital Storytelling
results.brief_description: After returning from World War II, having served in the RAAF as a Pathfinder, Peter Isaacson was appointed a Shrine of Remembrance Trustee. He discusses his time at the Shrine, as Chairman of the Shrine of Remembrance Trustees and the role of the Shrine in helping Australians remember as well as teaching those who don’t remember the history of Australia at war.

results.title: An Interview with Norm Smithells
results.creator_credit: Norm Smithells and ACMI Digital Storytelling
results.brief_description: Norm Smithells was a Spitfire pilot in Europe during World War II. He reflects on flying and fighting the Germans during this time and shares his history as there are not many pilots left.

results.title: An Interview with Jock McAuley
results.creator_credit: Jock McAuley and ACMI Digital Storytelling
results.brief_description: Jock McAuley remembers hearing Prime Minister Menzies announcing Australia was at war. He was only 15 or 16 at the time and wondered if the would be still going by the time he was old enough to join. Against his dad’s wishes, Jock joined up and served as a pilot during the war. He tells of his experiences fighting for Australia.

results.title: Angel in the house
results.creator_credit: Jane Jackson and British Film Institute
results.brief_description: The film takes as its theme an essay by Virginia Woolf written in 1927. In the essay Virginia Woolf talks about women writers and the psychological and social barriers to their creativity and their self-confidence. In 1977, the film’s protagonist Lily Ramsey is an aspiring writer, and an admirer of Virginia Woolf. In an attempt to complete her first novel, she takes a break from her job in London and goes home to the small seaside town where her family still lives. However, for Lily home is not simply a peaceful place to write, but part of the experience which she brings to bear on her writing.
